## Execution Flow

### Scenario 1: Push to Master

```
1. Developer: git push origin master
                    â†“
2. GitHub: master.yaml triggers (on: push)
                    â†“
3. Setup & Validate starts
   â””â”€ Setup Node.js + npm ci
   â””â”€ Run ESLint
                    â†“
4. If Setup passes (needed by others):
   â”œâ”€ Build starts
   â”œâ”€ Unit Tests start
   â””â”€ (parallel execution)
                    â†“
5. Build completes, E2E Tests start
                    â†“
6. All jobs done â†’ Summary reports status
```

### Scenario 2: Pull Request

```
1. Developer: git push origin feature-branch
   Then: Opens PR to master
                    â†“
2. GitHub: master.yaml triggers (on: pull_request)
                    â†“
3. Same as Scenario 1 but:
   â””â”€ GitHub requires pipeline to pass before merge
   â””â”€ Branch protection rules apply
```

### Scenario 3: Manual Trigger

```
1. GitHub UI: Actions â†’ Run workflow
                    â†“
2. Select branch (default: master)
                    â†“
3. Click "Run workflow"
                    â†“
4. Same as Scenario 1 - full pipeline executes
```

```
         â”‚

         â”‚
         â””â”€ Upload: GitHub Artifact Storage
                    (retention: 1 day)
                    â”‚
                    â””â”€ Download in E2E Tests job
                       â”‚
                       â””â”€ Use for Playwright tests
```

## Concurrency & Resource Management

```
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ Concurrency Control                â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ â€¢ Only 1 active run per branch     â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ In-progress runs: 20m timeout    â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ New push: cancel previous run    â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ Saves: GitHub Actions minutes   â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ Result: Faster feedback          â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Example:
  Run #1: In progress (Setup job)
  Developer: git push new changes
    â†“
  Run #1: CANCELLED (concurrency)
  Run #2: STARTED (new run)
```

## Performance Timeline

Typical execution for small project:

```
Setup & Validate:  â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘  ~6 min
Build Production:  â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘  ~12 min
Unit Tests:        â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘  ~13 min  â”
E2E Tests:         â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘  ~18 min  â”‚ Parallel
Summary:           â–ˆâ–ˆâ–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘  ~2 min   â”˜

Total: ~13-20 minutes
(Jobs run in parallel where possible)
```
